channel.title: Fucked up my XP installation
channel.description:
So I'm on my PC, turned it off at the wrong moment. Some shit got corrupted, so I repaired my Windows installation. Noting the extremely long start-up times (in the ballpark of a minute to go from fully off to Opera open and browsing), I also found out that I had to update my installation, as my repaired install of SP 1a had partially overwritten my SP 2 installation. I also found out that updating was impossible, as my ntoskrnl.exe seemed to be corrupted. Deciding this was too much for me to waste my time on, and having a week's worth of homework waiting to be finished, I'm going to fully reinstall Windows, for the second time in a month. How is the best way for me to go about transferring my programs and settings? I copied my Program Files folder to an external drive, as well as the Documents and Settings folder (including the Application Data folders). I also backed up my registry, though I fear that simply overwriting a fresh registry with the backed up one may cause problems. In addition, I had the Files and Settings Transfer Wizard create a settings file on the external HDD as well.
To sum it all up, I'm going to reinstall Windows. Can you guys help me ensure it is as smooth as possible? Any tricks, tips, programs, etc?

item.title: Fucked up my XP installation
item.dc:creator: @BlackThursday BlackThursday
item.description:
@BlackThursday wrote:

It sounds like your only option is gonna be a low-level format and a reinstall, bad luck mate

However, you can save your precious files on external HDD or a USB device so all is not lost

Read full topic

item.title: Fucked up my XP installation
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

On another topic

And anyway, where would you get a copy of a Mac installation?

Torrents. And like I said, it doesn’t work with SATA drives, so there is no need to talk about Leopard or Tiger here.

Read full topic

item.title: Fucked up my XP installation
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

ThugLife:

You know, you should really practice what you preach, because i am sure you run windows.

Tbh, he doesn’t know what he’s talking about.

item.title: Fucked up my XP installation
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

fellixombc:

Get linux or mac, both are better then windows. But if you want windows so bad, select the drive to save it on, make sure you have all your crap on a usb or something, put in the os disc, and wipe everything on the comp and install windows xp, once that is done, put your usb in…etc.

You know, you should really practice what you preach, because i am sure you run windows.

Read full topic

item.title: Fucked up my XP installation
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

Sorry, I misinterpreted what you had originally said :o.

For the programs, it would probably just be easier if you still had the installers to copy them to the external HDD and then just re-install, I’d personally not recommend replacing a registry with a backup, just because of all of the things that can go wrong.

If you want to transfer windows settings, I’m pretty sure the Files and Settings Transfer wizard can do that for you.

If you wanted to be bold and try to copy the existing directories of programs, as well as their registry keys, in theory it could work, but it’s probably not a good idea, a fresh installation is probably best (if you have the installers, that is).

Read full topic

item.title: Fucked up my XP installation
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

[quote=“VB7 Rocks, post:5, topic:172457”]The registry is just a section on the hard drive that you can’t access via Explorer, only the registry editor. It’s re-created if you re-install windows.

It really depends on how much of your existing installation you want to back up. If you want to keep all of your documents, etc., then you don’t really need to backup the registry.

All the registry is for is Windows related things, along with file associations, program install data, etc., nothing that’s really “important”, you don’t really need to transfer it unless there’s a specific reason.

If you’re looking to transfer things like personal settings, I’m not sure, but the files and transfer wizard might be able to create a settings file or something. However, I doubt doing something like replacing the registry would help, because of all of the excess data that would be in it.[/quote]

I understand what the registry is, and that it is recreated on fresh installation.

As I said, I want to just copy and paste to have my programs up and working. I don’t want to have to torrent installers and reinstall everything and set up my settings for each program. I just did it a month ago.

The registry replaces the .ini file. It contains options and settings for most installed programs, and I’m pretty sure it is “important.” If you have a source that says otherwise, then let me know.

Like I said,

xxlegitxx:

I had the Files and Settings Transfer Wizard create a settings file on the external HDD as well.

Successfully, though it only transfered OS-specific settings, little to do with programs. And considering I only had this computer for a month, I doubt there would be an excess of data.

Read full topic

item.title: Fucked up my XP installation
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

xxlegitxx:

Then what about my registry? Programs depend on that, don’t they? And I don’t want to copy my WINDOWS folder, considering that is probably the source of my problems.

The registry is just a section on the hard drive that you can’t access via Explorer, only the registry editor. It’s re-created if you re-install windows.

It really depends on how much of your existing installation you want to back up. If you want to keep all of your documents, etc., then you don’t really need to backup the registry.

All the registry is for is Windows related things, along with file associations, program install data, etc., nothing that’s really “important”, you don’t really need to transfer it unless there’s a specific reason.

If you’re looking to transfer things like personal settings, I’m not sure, but the files and transfer wizard might be able to create a settings file or something. However, I doubt doing something like replacing the registry would help, because of all of the excess data that would be in it.

Read full topic

item.title: Fucked up my XP installation
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

fellixombc:

Get linux or mac, both are better then windows. But if you want windows so bad, select the drive to save it on, make sure you have all your crap on a usb or something, put in the os disc, and wipe everything on the comp and install windows xp, once that is done, put your usb in…etc.

fellixombc:

Get linux or mac, both are better then windows. But if you want windows so bad, select the drive to save it on, make sure you have all your crap on a usb or something, put in the os disc, and wipe everything on the comp and install windows xp, once that is done, put your usb in…etc.

I appreciate your post, but you’re really not telling me anything I don’t already know. You don’t think that being the 3rd biggest spammer here, I would not have heard anything about Linux here? I’ved tried *buntu, and decided if ndiswrapper and sudo were such pains in the asses to work out, the rest of the OS wasn’t worth trying.

Mac OS X does not work with a SATA drive.

And I was trying to be able to work out transferring my settings and programs just by copying from the harddrive, without bringing any corrupted files from my C:/WINDOWS folder.

[quote=“VB7 Rocks, post:3, topic:172457”]That would be the one thing not to do. Do not replace a new registry with a back up.

To be honest, the best way to transfer your stuff would be to just write it all to external media like flash drives, DVD’s, external HDD’s, etc., and then just transfer it to the new installation.[/quote]

Then what about my registry? Programs depend on that, don’t they? And I don’t want to copy my WINDOWS folder, considering that is probably the source of my problems.

Read full topic

item.title: Fucked up my XP installation
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

xxlegitxx:

I also backed up my registry, though I fear that simply overwriting a fresh registry with the backed up one may cause problems.

That would be the one thing not to do. Do not replace a new registry with a back up.

To be honest, the best way to transfer your stuff would be to just write it all to external media like flash drives, DVD’s, external HDD’s, etc., and then just transfer it to the new installation.

Read full topic
